welcome back Ø¹Ø¯Ù†Ø§ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§Ù„ØºÙŠØ¨Ø© ğŸ˜… ğŸš€ Next Step: SWE.2 â€“ From Requirement to Architecture and Model! ğŸš€Iâ€™m thrilled to share the next phase of my MBD diploma project from OS-Academy â€“ : SWE.2 â€“ Software Architecture Design! ğŸš€In this stage, weâ€™ll take the system requirements defined in SWE.1 and build a modular, maintainable architecture that steers implementation, testing, and future evolution.Hereâ€™s what to expect:1ï¸âƒ£ Architectural Views Break the system into clear functional blocks and define their responsibilities:ğŸ”¹Main State Machine Manages core logic and coordinates inter-module communication.ğŸ”¹Current Limits Calculator Computes safe charge/discharge thresholds based on real-time data.ğŸ”¹SOC & SOH Estimators Tracks battery state-of-charge and state-of-health.ğŸ”¹Balancing Logic Ensures individual cell voltages stay synchronized.2ï¸âƒ£ Interfaces & Data FlowsMap each domain into software modules/packages with precise contracts: ğŸ”¹ Defined fixed-rate tasks(50 ms â” MainSM, 100 ms â” LimitsCalc, 200 ms â” SOC/SOH estimators, 250 ms â” Balancing) ğŸ”¹ Route signals (voltage, temperature, current) via buses and ZOH blocks ğŸ”¹ Store each signal in the Data Dictionary as ğŸ”„ a MTP Signals: (ImportedExtern (inputs) - ExportedToFile (logging) - Localized (module-internal))3ï¸âƒ£ Modeling & PrototypingLeverage MATLAB/Simulink & Stateflow to:ğŸ”¹Prototype each core module and simulate their interactions.ğŸ”¹Auto-generate architecture diagrams directly from models.ğŸ”¹Run Model Advisor checks for MISRA C compliance, execution efficiency, and RAM usage.4ï¸âƒ£ Verification AlignmentEmbed test hooks and traceability throughout:ğŸ”¹MIL/SIL Test Harnesses for unit, integration, and system-level validation.ğŸ”¹Full Requirements â†” Architecture â†” Test Case traceability matrices.ğŸ”¹Automated test-management reports to track coverage and results.ğŸ” Why it matters A well-crafted software architecture is the backbone of a reliable project â€”it makes implementation easier to develop, verify, and evolve. GCC15 is out, with prime path coverage! I wrote a paper about the my implementation, the algorithm, and some new developments; notably, that prime path coverage subsumes MC/DC, and that using suffix trees for recording paths can eliminate redundant paths very quickly -- O(nÂ²m) down from O(nÂ²mÂ²), where n is the length of the longest path, and m is the number of paths. This is makes pruning redundant paths very quick as n tends to be small, and m tends to be very large.

Up until recently Amethyst Planner stored everything locally on the user's device. Unfortunately this meant that the user couldn't use the app across multiple devices (or easy switch to a new device).I was surprised to find there wasn't an existing plugin for sync'ing data between Hive and a backend API. We ended up creating TimestampedBox that wraps a Hive Box and provides all the timestamps to support the sync operation. What do you think? How have you approached synchronization and reconciliation across devices and backends?Checkout Amethyst Planner - the task app for hashtag#ADHDers the turns to-dos into dopamine.

For professionals like me who architect systems with Hexagonal Architecture (DDD) and deploy on AWS, this release brings substantial benefits.ğŸš€ Key Features in Java 24:âœ… JEP 447 â€“ Statements before super(...) Allows initialization logic before calling the superclass constructor. This enhances flexibility in rich domain models and simplifies base-class inheritance patterns in DDD.âœ… JEP 456 â€“ Unnamed Variables and Patterns (Preview) Reduces boilerplate when using pattern matching, making business logic cleaner and more expressive.âœ… JEP 459 â€“ String Templates (Second Preview) Provides safe and efficient string interpolation â€” ideal for building dynamic responses, configurations, and messages without complex concatenation.âœ… JEP 460 â€“ Vector API (7th Incubator) Enables data-parallel operations for better performance in compute-heavy tasks â€” relevant for analytics or event-driven systems.âœ… JEP 462 â€“ Structured Concurrency (Second Preview) Improves thread lifecycle management and simplifies parallel processing. This is huge for backend services needing concurrency without chaos â€” perfect fit for services deployed via AWS Lambda, ECS, or EKS.ğŸ§± How this strengthens Hexagonal Architecture and DDDJava 24â€™s cleaner syntax and enhanced language constructs allow for: ğŸ”¹ Richer domain modeling without ceremony ğŸ”¹ Easier testing and mocking of application ports ğŸ”¹ Clearer separation of concerns in inbound/outbound adapters ğŸ”¹ Better observability and tracing when paired with AWS services like CloudWatch & X-Rayâ˜ï¸ AWS + Java 24 = Cloud-native powerCombined with AWS, Java 24 enables: âœ… Lighter Lambda functions (faster cold starts with JDK optimizations) âœ… Enhanced developer productivity with CodeWhisperer and Amazon Q Developer âœ… Seamless integration with infrastructure-as-code (CDK, Terraform) and microservices ecosystemsWeâ€™re not just writing code â€” weâ€™re building resilient, scalable ecosystems. Java 24 gives us sharper tools to do that smarter, faster, and cleaner.Are you already experimenting with Java 24? Last year, I developed a nonlinear Model Predictive Controller (nMPC) based local planner for a Differential Drive Mobile Robot (DDMR) within the ROS Noetic navigation stack.Unlike conventional reactive planners, an nMPC uses a mathematical model (in this case, a kinematic model) to predict future states and optimize them over a defined horizon. This is done by minimizing a cost function while satisfying both soft and hard constraints, such as obstacle distance, velocity bounds, and input limits.The local planner was implemented entirely in Python, utilizing the CasADi framework for formulating the nonlinear optimization problem. The IPOPT solver (Interior Point Optimizer) was used to solve the problem at runtime efficiently.As part of the evaluation, I compared the nMPC planner against established ROS local planners:- Dynamic Window Approach (DWA)- Timed Elastic Band (TEB)The nMPC planner receives a global reference trajectory (e.g., from an RRT-based global planner) and computes optimized control inputs at higher frequency to achieve smooth and safe local obstacle avoidance, even in dynamic and narrow environments.- The system was simulated in Gazebo with a TurtleBot platform and fully integrated with ROS Noetic.- ğŸ³ A GPU-enabled Docker container is provided for fast and reproducible setup.- ğŸ“ The GitHub repository includes the full source code, parameter tuning, scientific paper, and presentation slides.ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/dgpq7y2Yhashtag#Robotics hashtag#MPC hashtag#nMPC hashtag#CasADi hashtag#IPOPT hashtag#PathPlanning hashtag#ROS hashtag#ROSNoetic hashtag#AutonomousSystems hashtag#TurtleBot hashtag#Gazebo hashtag#Python hashtag#MobileRobots hashtag#NonlinearControl hashtag#ControlTheory hashtag#Optimization hashtag#ResearchProject hashtag#OpenSource

ğŸ§µ Multithreading Interview Q&A (Deep & Drive)Q1: What is multithreading in Java?-> Multithreading is a process of executing two or more threads simultaneously for maximum CPU utilization. Each thread runs independently, but they share the same process memory.Q2: How do you create threads in Java?-> Two ways:->Extend the Thread class and override run()->Implement Runnable and pass to the Thread constructorjavaCopyEdit->Runnable task = () -> System.out.println("Thread running"); new Thread(task).start();Q3: Difference between start() and run()?->start() creates a new thread and invokes run() inside it. run() just calls the method in the current thread (no parallelism).Q4: What is the thread lifecycle?->New â†’ Runnable â†’ Running â†’ Blocked/Waiting â†’ Dead. Transitions occur due to start(), I/O, wait/notify, etc.Q5: What are synchronized blocks?->Used to avoid race conditions when multiple threads modify shared   resources. Only one thread can enter a synchronized block for the given lock at a time.javaCopyEditsynchronized(this) { // critical section}Q6: What is the difference between synchronized and Lock?->Lock (like ReentrantLock) offers more control (tryLock, fairness), while synchronized is easier and less error-prone.Q7: What is the use of volatile keyword?->It prevents caching of variables, ensuring visibility of changes across threads.Q8: How do you handle thread communication?->Using wait(), notify(), notifyAll() inside synchronized blocks. Also, CountDownLatch, Semaphore, and  BlockingQueue are in the concurrent API.Q9: Thread-safe collections?->Use ConcurrentHashMap, CopyOnWriteArrayList, or wrap legacy ones via Collections.synchronizedList(...).Q10: How is multithreading used in Spring Boot?->Spring Boot uses multithreading in:Async tasks using @AsyncScheduled jobs (@Scheduled)Web server request handling (Tomcat/Jetty/NIO threads)Parallel data processing with WebClient + Project Reactor (Reactive Programming)hashtag#JavaDeveloper hashtag#TechInterview hashtag#BackendDevelopment hashtag#SpringBoot hashtag#JavaLearning hashtag#ProgrammingTipshashtag#JavaMultithreading hashtag#ConcurrencyInJava hashtag#ThreadSafety hashtag#ParallelProgramming hashtag#JavaThreads hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#JavaTips hashtag#AsynchronousProgramming hashtag#JavaInterview hashtag#JavaConcurrency hashtag#ThreadPool hashtag#CodeWithJava hashtag#MultithreadedApps hashtag#CoreJava hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

ğŸ“Œ Why Our Team is Considering Switching from Redis to Valkey: Real Performance Data and PerspectivesOur backend development team has been looking at Valkey as an alternative to Redis for quite some time, and I recently studied a detailed comparison of these technologies that I'd like to share.â“What is Valkey and why does it matter?Valkey is a fork of Redis that maintained the BSD 3-Clause license after Redis changed its licensing model in spring 2024. The key difference: Valkey remains fully open-source, without an enterprise version or commercial restrictions.â“What did the benchmarks show?Tests based on YCSB demonstrated thatÂ Valkey 8.0 outperforms both Redis 6.2 and Redis 7.2Â in all load scenarios. Particularly interesting is that Redis 7.2 often performs worse than version 6.2, confirming the experience of many teams who encountered regressions when upgrading.âš™ï¸ Technical improvements that impressed us:- Innovative approach to I/O threads: In Redis, I/O threads and the main thread often "wait" for each other. In Valkey, this is fixed â€” threads can work in parallel thanks to the use of atomics and task queues for each I/O thread.- Hash table optimization: Improved processor cache utilization through prefetch, significantly reducing data access latency.- Dual-channel replication: Moving the change buffer to the replica, reducing the risk of Out Of Memory on the primary during intensive workloads.- Key embedding: Storing short keys directly in the structure, saving 10-20% of RAM.- Extended metrics: New monitoring capabilities, including tracking load on individual cluster slots.ğŸ“ What's next?The active developer community around Valkey promises more dynamic project development. We plan to conduct our own testing in our infrastructure before making a final decision, but the initial data looks promising.Has anyone already switched to Valkey in production? I'd love to hear about your experience in the comments!hashtag#backend hashtag#golang hashtag#redis hashtag#ralkey hashtag#HighLoad hashtag#OpenSource

Iâ€™m pleased to share our recent publication in Mechanical Systems and Signal Processing journal, titled:â€œOptimizing bridge modal property estimation via quality-driven crowdsourced smartphone data selectionâ€This study presents a novel approach to improve the accuracy of absolute mode shape identification by evaluating and filtering crowdsourced smartphone-vehicle trip data based on its quality. While mobile sensing using smartphone data offers a scalable and low-cost solution for bridge monitoring, it is often affected by sensor noise, vehicle dynamics, and road surface variability.To address this, we proposed a quality score to quantify each tripâ€™s contribution to the identified mode shape and developed a supervised learning model (using CNNs) to automatically predict the data quality score. Our model was trained and validated using over 900 datasets collected on the Cadore Viaduct in Italy. The results demonstrated that filtering based on data quality can significantly enhance absolute mode shape accuracy.This work underscores the importance of data quality in mobile sensing for structural health monitoring and showcases the integration of data-driven methods into civil infrastructure assessment.I am sincerely grateful to my co-authors â€” Thomas Matarazzo, Soheil Sadeghi Eshkevari, Liam Cronin, and Shamim Pakzad â€” for their valuable contributions and collaboration throughout this work. I would also like to extend my thanks to MIT Senseable City Lab for their support and for providing access to datasets.The full paper is available open access at the following link: https://lnkd.in/dvUPt46thashtag#StructuralHealthMonitoring hashtag#MobileSensing hashtag#CrowdsourcedData hashtag#CivilEngineering hashtag#MachineLearning hashtag#BridgeMonitoring hashtag#MechanicalSystemsAndSignalProcessing hashtag#SHM hashtag#DataQuality hashtag#WaveletTransform

Who cares if remote employees are working multiple jobs?Shocking opinion, I know. But, honestly, why does it matter?If someone is doing their job well, why should I care if theyâ€™re working another one?I saw a report today that some remote employees MIGHT be working multiple jobs. Itâ€™s the type of article designed to produce outrage. Youâ€™re supposed to be shocked and scared. Maybe even move your team back to the office. But I have to ask, why do we care?People have been working multiple jobs for decades. As long as they produce at their current job (and itâ€™s not competitive), I vote: give them flexibility and let them use it how they see fit

"Sometimes when things fall apart, theyâ€™re actually falling into place."The past few months have brought real challenges and hardshipsâ€”and I donâ€™t want to downplay thatâ€”but they have also uncovered some unexpected gifts and new possibilities. I've been reflecting on how multifaceted change can be:1. Finding community close to home.As a remote worker, Iâ€™ve treasured my colleagues across the country and the world, but Iâ€™ve missed in-person connection. One silver lining of this disruption is discovering a whole network of like-minded professionals right here in Colorado. Dozens of us, doing similar work, were just a few miles apart and never knew it.2. Growing in new directions.Our entire sector is expanding its toolkit. Weâ€™re gaining new skills, discovering new passions, and developing new capabilities. When we come back together, weâ€™ll be bringing more to the table than ever beforeâ€”and channeling that straight into global impact.3. Solidarity over fragmentation.Before all this, our field could feel artificially divided: donors vs. implementers, primes vs. subs, direct hires vs. contractors. But this moment has reminded us that weâ€™re all on one team. When the international development sector returns, weâ€™ll be stronger, more connected, and more united than ever. ğŸš€In this stage, weâ€™ll take the system requirements defined in SWE.1 and build a modular, maintainable architecture that steers implementation, testing, and future evolution.Hereâ€™s what to expect:1ï¸âƒ£ Architectural Views Break the system into clear functional blocks and define their responsibilities:ğŸ”¹Main State Machine Manages core logic and coordinates inter-module communication.ğŸ”¹Current Limits Calculator Computes safe charge/discharge thresholds based on real-time data.ğŸ”¹SOC & SOH Estimators Tracks battery state-of-charge and state-of-health.ğŸ”¹Balancing Logic Ensures individual cell voltages stay synchronized.2ï¸âƒ£ Interfaces & Data FlowsMap each domain into software modules/packages with precise contracts: ğŸ”¹ Defined fixed-rate tasks(50 ms â” MainSM, 100 ms â” LimitsCalc, 200 ms â” SOC/SOH estimators, 250 ms â” Balancing) ğŸ”¹ Route signals (voltage, temperature, current) via buses and ZOH blocks ğŸ”¹ Store each signal in the Data Dictionary as ğŸ”„ a MTP Signals: (ImportedExtern (inputs) - ExportedToFile (logging) - Localized (module-internal))3ï¸âƒ£ Modeling & PrototypingLeverage MATLAB/Simulink & Stateflow to:ğŸ”¹Prototype each core module and simulate their interactions.ğŸ”¹Auto-generate architecture diagrams directly from models.ğŸ”¹Run Model Advisor checks for MISRA C compliance, execution efficiency, and RAM usage.4ï¸âƒ£ Verification AlignmentEmbed test hooks and traceability throughout:ğŸ”¹MIL/SIL Test Harnesses for unit, integration, and system-level validation.ğŸ”¹Full Requirements â†” Architecture â†” Test Case traceability matrices.ğŸ”¹Automated test-management reports to track coverage and results.ğŸ” Why it matters A well-crafted software architecture is the backbone of a reliable project â€”it makes implementation easier to develop, verify, and evolve. GCC15 is out, with prime path coverage! I wrote a paper about the my implementation, the algorithm, and some new developments; notably, that prime path coverage subsumes MC/DC, and that using suffix trees for recording paths can eliminate redundant paths very quickly -- O(nÂ²m) down from O(nÂ²mÂ²), where n is the length of the longest path, and m is the number of paths. This is makes pruning redundant paths very quick as n tends to be small, and m tends to be very large.

Up until recently Amethyst Planner stored everything locally on the user's device. Unfortunately this meant that the user couldn't use the app across multiple devices (or easy switch to a new device).I was surprised to find there wasn't an existing plugin for sync'ing data between Hive and a backend API. We ended up creating TimestampedBox that wraps a Hive Box and provides all the timestamps to support the sync operation. What do you think? How have you approached synchronization and reconciliation across devices and backends?Checkout Amethyst Planner - the task app for hashtag#ADHDers the turns to-dos into dopamine.

For many developers, firmware is a given, constraints that must be obeyed in production software.Â â€œBare-Metal Embedded C Programmingâ€ ( Packt , 2025) by Israel Ninsaw Gbati demonstrates, at a fundamental level, how coding firmware by directly activating system microcontrollers should be merely another step in the production process.Â Â The book consists of 18 chapters, starting with the basics, then discussing timers and system peripherals, before briefly touching on power management.Â I recommend this for any developer looking to extract the maximum performance from their coding. hashtag#baremetal hashtag#C hashtag#Software hashtag#firmware hashtag#Packt

Next, kita try module CH376S for this D0WD-v3 ESP32 which this MC very likely act as isolated network device, BUT possibility to send log about isolated network activity via COM, so boleh act sbg intermediary bagi pihak host2 dalam network dia sahaja dengan syarat physical connected dengan driver tertentu (COM) .. cumanya, kena tambah CH376S USB Module storage ntk keep logging â€˜somethingâ€™ and send to â€˜outside worldâ€™ via COM or guna STA sbb AP ntk MC ni xdpt nak implement full NAT Routing Capabilties ..But, this device boleh buat DDOS dengan capture packet, deauther develop by rinisek, could be Deauther ni operate in Layer 2 OSI, which is spam packets, frame injection, MAC Spoofing things, satu WiFi Radio dah boleh, but NAT Routing more to Layer 3 OSI & TCP/UDP ops, kena dual jugak WiFi Radio .. klu sketch Full NAT Implement tak boleh kat DW0D-V3, means sia2 sketch DNS Hijack, imo .. ğŸ˜µâ€ğŸ’«But this device sangat sesuai untuk OT Environment, same like SCADA, ASRS etc untuk logging and update, so dapat reduce penggunaan device yang mahal2 like router yang boleh expose TCP Stack, like my previous experience, 8 Crane Controller update logs to WMS Workload through Outdate MOXA Router, lol .. duit pun kena hentam kaw2 dengan vendor ntk maintenance, lambat satu hal, lagi besar attack surface beranak pinak satu hal .. teringat Moxa OS Zero-Day Exploit (RCE) last year, should fixed already ..hashtag#esp32 hashtag#microcontroller hashtag#learning hashtag#networksecurity

Java 24: More than an update â€” a powerful step forward for modern software architecture. hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBRWith the official release of Java 24, Oracle continues to evolve the platform in ways that directly support today's demands for scalability, modularity, and cloud-native design. For professionals like me who architect systems with Hexagonal Architecture (DDD) and deploy on AWS, this release brings substantial benefits.ğŸš€ Key Features in Java 24:âœ… JEP 447 â€“ Statements before super(...) Allows initialization logic before calling the superclass constructor. This enhances flexibility in rich domain models and simplifies base-class inheritance patterns in DDD.âœ… JEP 456 â€“ Unnamed Variables and Patterns (Preview) Reduces boilerplate when using pattern matching, making business logic cleaner and more expressive.âœ… JEP 459 â€“ String Templates (Second Preview) Provides safe and efficient string interpolation â€” ideal for building dynamic responses, configurations, and messages without complex concatenation.âœ… JEP 460 â€“ Vector API (7th Incubator) Enables data-parallel operations for better performance in compute-heavy tasks â€” relevant for analytics or event-driven systems.âœ… JEP 462 â€“ Structured Concurrency (Second Preview) Improves thread lifecycle management and simplifies parallel processing. This is huge for backend services needing concurrency without chaos â€” perfect fit for services deployed via AWS Lambda, ECS, or EKS.ğŸ§± How this strengthens Hexagonal Architecture and DDDJava 24â€™s cleaner syntax and enhanced language constructs allow for: ğŸ”¹ Richer domain modeling without ceremony ğŸ”¹ Easier testing and mocking of application ports ğŸ”¹ Clearer separation of concerns in inbound/outbound adapters ğŸ”¹ Better observability and tracing when paired with AWS services like CloudWatch & X-Rayâ˜ï¸ AWS + Java 24 = Cloud-native powerCombined with AWS, Java 24 enables: âœ… Lighter Lambda functions (faster cold starts with JDK optimizations) âœ… Enhanced developer productivity with CodeWhisperer and Amazon Q Developer âœ… Seamless integration with infrastructure-as-code (CDK, Terraform) and microservices ecosystemsWeâ€™re not just writing code â€” weâ€™re building resilient, scalable ecosystems. Java 24 gives us sharper tools to do that smarter, faster, and cleaner.Are you already experimenting with Java 24? Whatâ€™s your favorite improvement so far?hashtag#Java24 hashtag#HexagonalArchitecture hashtag#DDD hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudNative hashtag#Innovation hashtag#BackendEngineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBR

It's Friday and I'm still working. .One myth about remote work is how people think it's all about working from the "comfort" of your home. .It's not and most of the time, it's not comfortable. It still requires your time, excellence, commitment and consistency. .Sometimes, we forget to have breakfast. Other times, we make plans and forget about them because we get so engrossed in the work we do. We miss out on outside activities due to deadlines and even though we have the luxury of working from anywhere in the world, we can sit in a spot for hours, forgetting to stretch our bones. ğŸ˜Œ.As a remote workerâ€“on some daysâ€“I find it hard to balance personal and work life, so that I don't miss out on important occasions and information. .Are you a remote worker? Last year, I developed a nonlinear Model Predictive Controller (nMPC) based local planner for a Differential Drive Mobile Robot (DDMR) within the ROS Noetic navigation stack.Unlike conventional reactive planners, an nMPC uses a mathematical model (in this case, a kinematic model) to predict future states and optimize them over a defined horizon. This is done by minimizing a cost function while satisfying both soft and hard constraints, such as obstacle distance, velocity bounds, and input limits.The local planner was implemented entirely in Python, utilizing the CasADi framework for formulating the nonlinear optimization problem. The IPOPT solver (Interior Point Optimizer) was used to solve the problem at runtime efficiently.As part of the evaluation, I compared the nMPC planner against established ROS local planners:- Dynamic Window Approach (DWA)- Timed Elastic Band (TEB)The nMPC planner receives a global reference trajectory (e.g., from an RRT-based global planner) and computes optimized control inputs at higher frequency to achieve smooth and safe local obstacle avoidance, even in dynamic and narrow environments.- The system was simulated in Gazebo with a TurtleBot platform and fully integrated with ROS Noetic.- ğŸ³ A GPU-enabled Docker container is provided for fast and reproducible setup.- ğŸ“ The GitHub repository includes the full source code, parameter tuning, scientific paper, and presentation slides.ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/dgpq7y2Yhashtag#Robotics hashtag#MPC hashtag#nMPC hashtag#CasADi hashtag#IPOPT hashtag#PathPlanning hashtag#ROS hashtag#ROSNoetic hashtag#AutonomousSystems hashtag#TurtleBot hashtag#Gazebo hashtag#Python hashtag#MobileRobots hashtag#NonlinearControl hashtag#ControlTheory hashtag#Optimization hashtag#ResearchProject hashtag#OpenSource

ğŸ§µ Multithreading Interview Q&A (Deep & Drive)Q1: What is multithreading in Java?-> Multithreading is a process of executing two or more threads simultaneously for maximum CPU utilization. Each thread runs independently, but they share the same process memory.Q2: How do you create threads in Java?-> Two ways:->Extend the Thread class and override run()->Implement Runnable and pass to the Thread constructorjavaCopyEdit->Runnable task = () -> System.out.println("Thread running"); new Thread(task).start();Q3: Difference between start() and run()?->start() creates a new thread and invokes run() inside it. run() just calls the method in the current thread (no parallelism).Q4: What is the thread lifecycle?->New â†’ Runnable â†’ Running â†’ Blocked/Waiting â†’ Dead. Transitions occur due to start(), I/O, wait/notify, etc.Q5: What are synchronized blocks?->Used to avoid race conditions when multiple threads modify shared   resources. Only one thread can enter a synchronized block for the given lock at a time.javaCopyEditsynchronized(this) { // critical section}Q6: What is the difference between synchronized and Lock?->Lock (like ReentrantLock) offers more control (tryLock, fairness), while synchronized is easier and less error-prone.Q7: What is the use of volatile keyword?->It prevents caching of variables, ensuring visibility of changes across threads.Q8: How do you handle thread communication?->Using wait(), notify(), notifyAll() inside synchronized blocks. Also, CountDownLatch, Semaphore, and  BlockingQueue are in the concurrent API.Q9: Thread-safe collections?->Use ConcurrentHashMap, CopyOnWriteArrayList, or wrap legacy ones via Collections.synchronizedList(...).Q10: How is multithreading used in Spring Boot?->Spring Boot uses multithreading in:Async tasks using @AsyncScheduled jobs (@Scheduled)Web server request handling (Tomcat/Jetty/NIO threads)Parallel data processing with WebClient + Project Reactor (Reactive Programming)hashtag#JavaDeveloper hashtag#TechInterview hashtag#BackendDevelopment hashtag#SpringBoot hashtag#JavaLearning hashtag#ProgrammingTipshashtag#JavaMultithreading hashtag#ConcurrencyInJava hashtag#ThreadSafety hashtag#ParallelProgramming hashtag#JavaThreads hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#JavaTips hashtag#AsynchronousProgramming hashtag#JavaInterview hashtag#JavaConcurrency hashtag#ThreadPool hashtag#CodeWithJava hashtag#MultithreadedApps hashtag#CoreJava hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

ğŸ“Œ Why Our Team is Considering Switching from Redis to Valkey: Real Performance Data and PerspectivesOur backend development team has been looking at Valkey as an alternative to Redis for quite some time, and I recently studied a detailed comparison of these technologies that I'd like to share.â“What is Valkey and why does it matter?Valkey is a fork of Redis that maintained the BSD 3-Clause license after Redis changed its licensing model in spring 2024. The key difference: Valkey remains fully open-source, without an enterprise version or commercial restrictions.â“What did the benchmarks show?Tests based on YCSB demonstrated thatÂ Valkey 8.0 outperforms both Redis 6.2 and Redis 7.2Â in all load scenarios. Particularly interesting is that Redis 7.2 often performs worse than version 6.2, confirming the experience of many teams who encountered regressions when upgrading.âš™ï¸ Technical improvements that impressed us:- Innovative approach to I/O threads: In Redis, I/O threads and the main thread often "wait" for each other. In Valkey, this is fixed â€” threads can work in parallel thanks to the use of atomics and task queues for each I/O thread.- Hash table optimization: Improved processor cache utilization through prefetch, significantly reducing data access latency.- Dual-channel replication: Moving the change buffer to the replica, reducing the risk of Out Of Memory on the primary during intensive workloads.- Key embedding: Storing short keys directly in the structure, saving 10-20% of RAM.- Extended metrics: New monitoring capabilities, including tracking load on individual cluster slots.ğŸ“ What's next?The active developer community around Valkey promises more dynamic project development. We plan to conduct our own testing in our infrastructure before making a final decision, but the initial data looks promising.Has anyone already switched to Valkey in production? I'd love to hear about your experience in the comments!hashtag#backend hashtag#golang hashtag#redis hashtag#ralkey hashtag#HighLoad hashtag#OpenSource

Iâ€™m pleased to share our recent publication in Mechanical Systems and Signal Processing journal, titled:â€œOptimizing bridge modal property estimation via quality-driven crowdsourced smartphone data selectionâ€This study presents a novel approach to improve the accuracy of absolute mode shape identification by evaluating and filtering crowdsourced smartphone-vehicle trip data based on its quality. While mobile sensing using smartphone data offers a scalable and low-cost solution for bridge monitoring, it is often affected by sensor noise, vehicle dynamics, and road surface variability.To address this, we proposed a quality score to quantify each tripâ€™s contribution to the identified mode shape and developed a supervised learning model (using CNNs) to automatically predict the data quality score. Our model was trained and validated using over 900 datasets collected on the Cadore Viaduct in Italy. The results demonstrated that filtering based on data quality can significantly enhance absolute mode shape accuracy.This work underscores the importance of data quality in mobile sensing for structural health monitoring and showcases the integration of data-driven methods into civil infrastructure assessment.I am sincerely grateful to my co-authors â€” Thomas Matarazzo, Soheil Sadeghi Eshkevari, Liam Cronin, and Shamim Pakzad â€” for their valuable contributions and collaboration throughout this work. I would also like to extend my thanks to MIT Senseable City Lab for their support and for providing access to datasets.The full paper is available open access at the following link: https://lnkd.in/dvUPt46thashtag#StructuralHealthMonitoring hashtag#MobileSensing hashtag#CrowdsourcedData hashtag#CivilEngineering hashtag#MachineLearning hashtag#BridgeMonitoring hashtag#MechanicalSystemsAndSignalProcessing hashtag#SHM hashtag#DataQuality hashtag#WaveletTransform

"Sometimes when things fall apart, theyâ€™re actually falling into place."The past few months have brought real challenges and hardshipsâ€”and I donâ€™t want to downplay thatâ€”but they have also uncovered some unexpected gifts and new possibilities. I've been reflecting on how multifaceted change can be:1. Finding community close to home.As a remote worker, Iâ€™ve treasured my colleagues across the country and the world, but Iâ€™ve missed in-person connection. One silver lining of this disruption is discovering a whole network of like-minded professionals right here in Colorado. Dozens of us, doing similar work, were just a few miles apart and never knew it.2. Growing in new directions.Our entire sector is expanding its toolkit. Weâ€™re gaining new skills, discovering new passions, and developing new capabilities. When we come back together, weâ€™ll be bringing more to the table than ever beforeâ€”and channeling that straight into global impact.3. Solidarity over fragmentation.Before all this, our field could feel artificially divided: donors vs. implementers, primes vs. subs, direct hires vs. contractors. But this moment has reminded us that weâ€™re all on one team. When the international development sector returns, weâ€™ll be stronger, more connected, and more united than ever. Get ready! hashtag#USAIDForever hashtag#InternationalDevelopment hashtag#EmbracingChange

Bravo, Michael Graff et co.! I recently added simple metrics (healthz, traffic, analysis) for a monitoring service while SLOs were being defined by others. That got me thinking about how to map SLOs <-> SLIs and KPIs <-> metrics <-> registers via OTel collectors (DPU/GPU/CPU HW/SW interfaces, anyone?). But then it got me thinking about how one would monitor dynamic HW/SW elements in a heterogeneous AI Infra fabric, leading to my current investigation of out-of-band management using OpenBMC on an evb-ast2600 board using Qemu-based HW emulation. Chip sounds like an important component in such a solution! And veddy much just in time! Congrats and thanks! ğŸ—ï¸ğŸ¤“ğŸ‰

ğŸš€In this stage, weâ€™ll take the system requirements defined in SWE.1 and build a modular, maintainable architecture that steers implementation, testing, and future evolution.Hereâ€™s what to expect:1ï¸âƒ£ Architectural Views Break the system into clear functional blocks and define their responsibilities:ğŸ”¹Main State Machine Manages core logic and coordinates inter-module communication.ğŸ”¹Current Limits Calculator Computes safe charge/discharge thresholds based on real-time data.ğŸ”¹SOC & SOH Estimators Tracks battery state-of-charge and state-of-health.ğŸ”¹Balancing Logic Ensures individual cell voltages stay synchronized.2ï¸âƒ£ Interfaces & Data FlowsMap each domain into software modules/packages with precise contracts: ğŸ”¹ Defined fixed-rate tasks(50 ms â” MainSM, 100 ms â” LimitsCalc, 200 ms â” SOC/SOH estimators, 250 ms â” Balancing) ğŸ”¹ Route signals (voltage, temperature, current) via buses and ZOH blocks ğŸ”¹ Store each signal in the Data Dictionary as ğŸ”„ a MTP Signals: (ImportedExtern (inputs) - ExportedToFile (logging) - Localized (module-internal))3ï¸âƒ£ Modeling & PrototypingLeverage MATLAB/Simulink & Stateflow to:ğŸ”¹Prototype each core module and simulate their interactions.ğŸ”¹Auto-generate architecture diagrams directly from models.ğŸ”¹Run Model Advisor checks for MISRA C compliance, execution efficiency, and RAM usage.4ï¸âƒ£ Verification AlignmentEmbed test hooks and traceability throughout:ğŸ”¹MIL/SIL Test Harnesses for unit, integration, and system-level validation.ğŸ”¹Full Requirements â†” Architecture â†” Test Case traceability matrices.ğŸ”¹Automated test-management reports to track coverage and results.ğŸ” Why it matters A well-crafted software architecture is the backbone of a reliable project â€”it makes implementation easier to develop, verify, and evolve. GCC15 is out, with prime path coverage! I wrote a paper about the my implementation, the algorithm, and some new developments; notably, that prime path coverage subsumes MC/DC, and that using suffix trees for recording paths can eliminate redundant paths very quickly -- O(nÂ²m) down from O(nÂ²mÂ²), where n is the length of the longest path, and m is the number of paths. This is makes pruning redundant paths very quick as n tends to be small, and m tends to be very large.

Up until recently Amethyst Planner stored everything locally on the user's device. Unfortunately this meant that the user couldn't use the app across multiple devices (or easy switch to a new device).I was surprised to find there wasn't an existing plugin for sync'ing data between Hive and a backend API. We ended up creating TimestampedBox that wraps a Hive Box and provides all the timestamps to support the sync operation. What do you think? How have you approached synchronization and reconciliation across devices and backends?Checkout Amethyst Planner - the task app for hashtag#ADHDers the turns to-dos into dopamine.

For many developers, firmware is a given, constraints that must be obeyed in production software.Â â€œBare-Metal Embedded C Programmingâ€ ( Packt , 2025) by Israel Ninsaw Gbati demonstrates, at a fundamental level, how coding firmware by directly activating system microcontrollers should be merely another step in the production process.Â Â The book consists of 18 chapters, starting with the basics, then discussing timers and system peripherals, before briefly touching on power management.Â I recommend this for any developer looking to extract the maximum performance from their coding. hashtag#baremetal hashtag#C hashtag#Software hashtag#firmware hashtag#Packt

Next, kita try module CH376S for this D0WD-v3 ESP32 which this MC very likely act as isolated network device, BUT possibility to send log about isolated network activity via COM, so boleh act sbg intermediary bagi pihak host2 dalam network dia sahaja dengan syarat physical connected dengan driver tertentu (COM) .. cumanya, kena tambah CH376S USB Module storage ntk keep logging â€˜somethingâ€™ and send to â€˜outside worldâ€™ via COM or guna STA sbb AP ntk MC ni xdpt nak implement full NAT Routing Capabilties ..But, this device boleh buat DDOS dengan capture packet, deauther develop by rinisek, could be Deauther ni operate in Layer 2 OSI, which is spam packets, frame injection, MAC Spoofing things, satu WiFi Radio dah boleh, but NAT Routing more to Layer 3 OSI & TCP/UDP ops, kena dual jugak WiFi Radio .. klu sketch Full NAT Implement tak boleh kat DW0D-V3, means sia2 sketch DNS Hijack, imo .. ğŸ˜µâ€ğŸ’«But this device sangat sesuai untuk OT Environment, same like SCADA, ASRS etc untuk logging and update, so dapat reduce penggunaan device yang mahal2 like router yang boleh expose TCP Stack, like my previous experience, 8 Crane Controller update logs to WMS Workload through Outdate MOXA Router, lol .. duit pun kena hentam kaw2 dengan vendor ntk maintenance, lambat satu hal, lagi besar attack surface beranak pinak satu hal .. teringat Moxa OS Zero-Day Exploit (RCE) last year, should fixed already ..hashtag#esp32 hashtag#microcontroller hashtag#learning hashtag#networksecurity

Java 24: More than an update â€” a powerful step forward for modern software architecture. hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBRWith the official release of Java 24, Oracle continues to evolve the platform in ways that directly support today's demands for scalability, modularity, and cloud-native design. For professionals like me who architect systems with Hexagonal Architecture (DDD) and deploy on AWS, this release brings substantial benefits.ğŸš€ Key Features in Java 24:âœ… JEP 447 â€“ Statements before super(...) Allows initialization logic before calling the superclass constructor. This enhances flexibility in rich domain models and simplifies base-class inheritance patterns in DDD.âœ… JEP 456 â€“ Unnamed Variables and Patterns (Preview) Reduces boilerplate when using pattern matching, making business logic cleaner and more expressive.âœ… JEP 459 â€“ String Templates (Second Preview) Provides safe and efficient string interpolation â€” ideal for building dynamic responses, configurations, and messages without complex concatenation.âœ… JEP 460 â€“ Vector API (7th Incubator) Enables data-parallel operations for better performance in compute-heavy tasks â€” relevant for analytics or event-driven systems.âœ… JEP 462 â€“ Structured Concurrency (Second Preview) Improves thread lifecycle management and simplifies parallel processing. This is huge for backend services needing concurrency without chaos â€” perfect fit for services deployed via AWS Lambda, ECS, or EKS.ğŸ§± How this strengthens Hexagonal Architecture and DDDJava 24â€™s cleaner syntax and enhanced language constructs allow for: ğŸ”¹ Richer domain modeling without ceremony ğŸ”¹ Easier testing and mocking of application ports ğŸ”¹ Clearer separation of concerns in inbound/outbound adapters ğŸ”¹ Better observability and tracing when paired with AWS services like CloudWatch & X-Rayâ˜ï¸ AWS + Java 24 = Cloud-native powerCombined with AWS, Java 24 enables: âœ… Lighter Lambda functions (faster cold starts with JDK optimizations) âœ… Enhanced developer productivity with CodeWhisperer and Amazon Q Developer âœ… Seamless integration with infrastructure-as-code (CDK, Terraform) and microservices ecosystemsWeâ€™re not just writing code â€” weâ€™re building resilient, scalable ecosystems. Java 24 gives us sharper tools to do that smarter, faster, and cleaner.Are you already experimenting with Java 24? Whatâ€™s your favorite improvement so far?hashtag#Java24 hashtag#HexagonalArchitecture hashtag#DDD hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudNative hashtag#Innovation hashtag#BackendEngineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBR

It's Friday and I'm still working. .One myth about remote work is how people think it's all about working from the "comfort" of your home. .It's not and most of the time, it's not comfortable. It still requires your time, excellence, commitment and consistency. .Sometimes, we forget to have breakfast. Other times, we make plans and forget about them because we get so engrossed in the work we do. We miss out on outside activities due to deadlines and even though we have the luxury of working from anywhere in the world, we can sit in a spot for hours, forgetting to stretch our bones. ğŸ˜Œ.As a remote workerâ€“on some daysâ€“I find it hard to balance personal and work life, so that I don't miss out on important occasions and information. .Are you a remote worker? Last year, I developed a nonlinear Model Predictive Controller (nMPC) based local planner for a Differential Drive Mobile Robot (DDMR) within the ROS Noetic navigation stack.Unlike conventional reactive planners, an nMPC uses a mathematical model (in this case, a kinematic model) to predict future states and optimize them over a defined horizon. This is done by minimizing a cost function while satisfying both soft and hard constraints, such as obstacle distance, velocity bounds, and input limits.The local planner was implemented entirely in Python, utilizing the CasADi framework for formulating the nonlinear optimization problem. The IPOPT solver (Interior Point Optimizer) was used to solve the problem at runtime efficiently.As part of the evaluation, I compared the nMPC planner against established ROS local planners:- Dynamic Window Approach (DWA)- Timed Elastic Band (TEB)The nMPC planner receives a global reference trajectory (e.g., from an RRT-based global planner) and computes optimized control inputs at higher frequency to achieve smooth and safe local obstacle avoidance, even in dynamic and narrow environments.- The system was simulated in Gazebo with a TurtleBot platform and fully integrated with ROS Noetic.- ğŸ³ A GPU-enabled Docker container is provided for fast and reproducible setup.- ğŸ“ The GitHub repository includes the full source code, parameter tuning, scientific paper, and presentation slides.ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/dgpq7y2Yhashtag#Robotics hashtag#MPC hashtag#nMPC hashtag#CasADi hashtag#IPOPT hashtag#PathPlanning hashtag#ROS hashtag#ROSNoetic hashtag#AutonomousSystems hashtag#TurtleBot hashtag#Gazebo hashtag#Python hashtag#MobileRobots hashtag#NonlinearControl hashtag#ControlTheory hashtag#Optimization hashtag#ResearchProject hashtag#OpenSource

ğŸ§µ Multithreading Interview Q&A (Deep & Drive)Q1: What is multithreading in Java?-> Multithreading is a process of executing two or more threads simultaneously for maximum CPU utilization. Each thread runs independently, but they share the same process memory.Q2: How do you create threads in Java?-> Two ways:->Extend the Thread class and override run()->Implement Runnable and pass to the Thread constructorjavaCopyEdit->Runnable task = () -> System.out.println("Thread running"); new Thread(task).start();Q3: Difference between start() and run()?->start() creates a new thread and invokes run() inside it. run() just calls the method in the current thread (no parallelism).Q4: What is the thread lifecycle?->New â†’ Runnable â†’ Running â†’ Blocked/Waiting â†’ Dead. Transitions occur due to start(), I/O, wait/notify, etc.Q5: What are synchronized blocks?->Used to avoid race conditions when multiple threads modify shared   resources. Only one thread can enter a synchronized block for the given lock at a time.javaCopyEditsynchronized(this) { // critical section}Q6: What is the difference between synchronized and Lock?->Lock (like ReentrantLock) offers more control (tryLock, fairness), while synchronized is easier and less error-prone.Q7: What is the use of volatile keyword?->It prevents caching of variables, ensuring visibility of changes across threads.Q8: How do you handle thread communication?->Using wait(), notify(), notifyAll() inside synchronized blocks. Also, CountDownLatch, Semaphore, and  BlockingQueue are in the concurrent API.Q9: Thread-safe collections?->Use ConcurrentHashMap, CopyOnWriteArrayList, or wrap legacy ones via Collections.synchronizedList(...).Q10: How is multithreading used in Spring Boot?->Spring Boot uses multithreading in:Async tasks using @AsyncScheduled jobs (@Scheduled)Web server request handling (Tomcat/Jetty/NIO threads)Parallel data processing with WebClient + Project Reactor (Reactive Programming)hashtag#JavaDeveloper hashtag#TechInterview hashtag#BackendDevelopment hashtag#SpringBoot hashtag#JavaLearning hashtag#ProgrammingTipshashtag#JavaMultithreading hashtag#ConcurrencyInJava hashtag#ThreadSafety hashtag#ParallelProgramming hashtag#JavaThreads hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#JavaTips hashtag#AsynchronousProgramming hashtag#JavaInterview hashtag#JavaConcurrency hashtag#ThreadPool hashtag#CodeWithJava hashtag#MultithreadedApps hashtag#CoreJava hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

ğŸ“Œ Why Our Team is Considering Switching from Redis to Valkey: Real Performance Data and PerspectivesOur backend development team has been looking at Valkey as an alternative to Redis for quite some time, and I recently studied a detailed comparison of these technologies that I'd like to share.â“What is Valkey and why does it matter?Valkey is a fork of Redis that maintained the BSD 3-Clause license after Redis changed its licensing model in spring 2024. The key difference: Valkey remains fully open-source, without an enterprise version or commercial restrictions.â“What did the benchmarks show?Tests based on YCSB demonstrated thatÂ Valkey 8.0 outperforms both Redis 6.2 and Redis 7.2Â in all load scenarios. Particularly interesting is that Redis 7.2 often performs worse than version 6.2, confirming the experience of many teams who encountered regressions when upgrading.âš™ï¸ Technical improvements that impressed us:- Innovative approach to I/O threads: In Redis, I/O threads and the main thread often "wait" for each other. In Valkey, this is fixed â€” threads can work in parallel thanks to the use of atomics and task queues for each I/O thread.- Hash table optimization: Improved processor cache utilization through prefetch, significantly reducing data access latency.- Dual-channel replication: Moving the change buffer to the replica, reducing the risk of Out Of Memory on the primary during intensive workloads.- Key embedding: Storing short keys directly in the structure, saving 10-20% of RAM.- Extended metrics: New monitoring capabilities, including tracking load on individual cluster slots.ğŸ“ What's next?The active developer community around Valkey promises more dynamic project development. We plan to conduct our own testing in our infrastructure before making a final decision, but the initial data looks promising.Has anyone already switched to Valkey in production? I'd love to hear about your experience in the comments!hashtag#backend hashtag#golang hashtag#redis hashtag#ralkey hashtag#HighLoad hashtag#OpenSource

Iâ€™m pleased to share our recent publication in Mechanical Systems and Signal Processing journal, titled:â€œOptimizing bridge modal property estimation via quality-driven crowdsourced smartphone data selectionâ€This study presents a novel approach to improve the accuracy of absolute mode shape identification by evaluating and filtering crowdsourced smartphone-vehicle trip data based on its quality. While mobile sensing using smartphone data offers a scalable and low-cost solution for bridge monitoring, it is often affected by sensor noise, vehicle dynamics, and road surface variability.To address this, we proposed a quality score to quantify each tripâ€™s contribution to the identified mode shape and developed a supervised learning model (using CNNs) to automatically predict the data quality score. Our model was trained and validated using over 900 datasets collected on the Cadore Viaduct in Italy. The results demonstrated that filtering based on data quality can significantly enhance absolute mode shape accuracy.This work underscores the importance of data quality in mobile sensing for structural health monitoring and showcases the integration of data-driven methods into civil infrastructure assessment.I am sincerely grateful to my co-authors â€” Thomas Matarazzo, Soheil Sadeghi Eshkevari, Liam Cronin, and Shamim Pakzad â€” for their valuable contributions and collaboration throughout this work. I would also like to extend my thanks to MIT Senseable City Lab for their support and for providing access to datasets.The full paper is available open access at the following link: https://lnkd.in/dvUPt46thashtag#StructuralHealthMonitoring hashtag#MobileSensing hashtag#CrowdsourcedData hashtag#CivilEngineering hashtag#MachineLearning hashtag#BridgeMonitoring hashtag#MechanicalSystemsAndSignalProcessing hashtag#SHM hashtag#DataQuality hashtag#WaveletTransform

"Sometimes when things fall apart, theyâ€™re actually falling into place."The past few months have brought real challenges and hardshipsâ€”and I donâ€™t want to downplay thatâ€”but they have also uncovered some unexpected gifts and new possibilities. I've been reflecting on how multifaceted change can be:1. Finding community close to home.As a remote worker, Iâ€™ve treasured my colleagues across the country and the world, but Iâ€™ve missed in-person connection. One silver lining of this disruption is discovering a whole network of like-minded professionals right here in Colorado. Dozens of us, doing similar work, were just a few miles apart and never knew it.2. Growing in new directions.Our entire sector is expanding its toolkit. Weâ€™re gaining new skills, discovering new passions, and developing new capabilities. When we come back together, weâ€™ll be bringing more to the table than ever beforeâ€”and channeling that straight into global impact.3. Solidarity over fragmentation.Before all this, our field could feel artificially divided: donors vs. implementers, primes vs. subs, direct hires vs. contractors. But this moment has reminded us that weâ€™re all on one team. When the international development sector returns, weâ€™ll be stronger, more connected, and more united than ever. Get ready! hashtag#USAIDForever hashtag#InternationalDevelopment hashtag#EmbracingChange

welcome back Ø¹Ø¯Ù†Ø§ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§Ù„ØºÙŠØ¨Ø© ğŸ˜… ğŸš€ Next Step: SWE.2 â€“ From Requirement to Architecture and Model! ğŸš€Iâ€™m thrilled to share the next phase of my MBD diploma project from OS-Academy â€“ : SWE.2 â€“ Software Architecture Design! ğŸš€In this stage, weâ€™ll take the system requirements defined in SWE.1 and build a modular, maintainable architecture that steers implementation, testing, and future evolution.Hereâ€™s what to expect:1ï¸âƒ£ Architectural Views Break the system into clear functional blocks and define their responsibilities:ğŸ”¹Main State Machine Manages core logic and coordinates inter-module communication.ğŸ”¹Current Limits Calculator Computes safe charge/discharge thresholds based on real-time data.ğŸ”¹SOC & SOH Estimators Tracks battery state-of-charge and state-of-health.ğŸ”¹Balancing Logic Ensures individual cell voltages stay synchronized.2ï¸âƒ£ Interfaces & Data FlowsMap each domain into software modules/packages with precise contracts: ğŸ”¹ Defined fixed-rate tasks(50 ms â” MainSM, 100 ms â” LimitsCalc, 200 ms â” SOC/SOH estimators, 250 ms â” Balancing) ğŸ”¹ Route signals (voltage, temperature, current) via buses and ZOH blocks ğŸ”¹ Store each signal in the Data Dictionary as ğŸ”„ a MTP Signals: (ImportedExtern (inputs) - ExportedToFile (logging) - Localized (module-internal))3ï¸âƒ£ Modeling & PrototypingLeverage MATLAB/Simulink & Stateflow to:ğŸ”¹Prototype each core module and simulate their interactions.ğŸ”¹Auto-generate architecture diagrams directly from models.ğŸ”¹Run Model Advisor checks for MISRA C compliance, execution efficiency, and RAM usage.4ï¸âƒ£ Verification AlignmentEmbed test hooks and traceability throughout:ğŸ”¹MIL/SIL Test Harnesses for unit, integration, and system-level validation.ğŸ”¹Full Requirements â†” Architecture â†” Test Case traceability matrices.ğŸ”¹Automated test-management reports to track coverage and results.ğŸ” Why it matters A well-crafted software architecture is the backbone of a reliable project â€”it makes implementation easier to develop, verify, and evolve. By nailing this SWE.2 step, we set ourselves up for smoother integration (SWE.3) and rigorous validation (SWE.4).ğŸ”— the GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dpww-PjNStay tuned for SWE.3, where we dive into detailed design and implementation, plus start exploring our battery and planetary models! ğŸŒğŸ”‹hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#MBD hashtag#VModel hashtag#SWE2 hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MATLABSimulink hashtag#BMS

GCC15 is out, with prime path coverage! I wrote a paper about the my implementation, the algorithm, and some new developments; notably, that prime path coverage subsumes MC/DC, and that using suffix trees for recording paths can eliminate redundant paths very quickly -- O(nÂ²m) down from O(nÂ²mÂ²), where n is the length of the longest path, and m is the number of paths. This is makes pruning redundant paths very quick as n tends to be small, and m tends to be very large.

Up until recently Amethyst Planner stored everything locally on the user's device. Unfortunately this meant that the user couldn't use the app across multiple devices (or easy switch to a new device).I was surprised to find there wasn't an existing plugin for sync'ing data between Hive and a backend API. We ended up creating TimestampedBox that wraps a Hive Box and provides all the timestamps to support the sync operation. What do you think? How have you approached synchronization and reconciliation across devices and backends?Checkout Amethyst Planner - the task app for hashtag#ADHDers the turns to-dos into dopamine.

Java 24: More than an update â€” a powerful step forward for modern software architecture. hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBRWith the official release of Java 24, Oracle continues to evolve the platform in ways that directly support today's demands for scalability, modularity, and cloud-native design. For professionals like me who architect systems with Hexagonal Architecture (DDD) and deploy on AWS, this release brings substantial benefits.ğŸš€ Key Features in Java 24:âœ… JEP 447 â€“ Statements before super(...) Allows initialization logic before calling the superclass constructor. This enhances flexibility in rich domain models and simplifies base-class inheritance patterns in DDD.âœ… JEP 456 â€“ Unnamed Variables and Patterns (Preview) Reduces boilerplate when using pattern matching, making business logic cleaner and more expressive.âœ… JEP 459 â€“ String Templates (Second Preview) Provides safe and efficient string interpolation â€” ideal for building dynamic responses, configurations, and messages without complex concatenation.âœ… JEP 460 â€“ Vector API (7th Incubator) Enables data-parallel operations for better performance in compute-heavy tasks â€” relevant for analytics or event-driven systems.âœ… JEP 462 â€“ Structured Concurrency (Second Preview) Improves thread lifecycle management and simplifies parallel processing. This is huge for backend services needing concurrency without chaos â€” perfect fit for services deployed via AWS Lambda, ECS, or EKS.ğŸ§± How this strengthens Hexagonal Architecture and DDDJava 24â€™s cleaner syntax and enhanced language constructs allow for: ğŸ”¹ Richer domain modeling without ceremony ğŸ”¹ Easier testing and mocking of application ports ğŸ”¹ Clearer separation of concerns in inbound/outbound adapters ğŸ”¹ Better observability and tracing when paired with AWS services like CloudWatch & X-Rayâ˜ï¸ AWS + Java 24 = Cloud-native powerCombined with AWS, Java 24 enables: âœ… Lighter Lambda functions (faster cold starts with JDK optimizations) âœ… Enhanced developer productivity with CodeWhisperer and Amazon Q Developer âœ… Seamless integration with infrastructure-as-code (CDK, Terraform) and microservices ecosystemsWeâ€™re not just writing code â€” weâ€™re building resilient, scalable ecosystems. Java 24 gives us sharper tools to do that smarter, faster, and cleaner.Are you already experimenting with Java 24? Whatâ€™s your favorite improvement so far?hashtag#Java24 hashtag#HexagonalArchitecture hashtag#DDD hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudNative hashtag#Innovation hashtag#BackendEngineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBR

Other times, we make plans and forget about them because we get so engrossed in the work we do. Last year, I developed a nonlinear Model Predictive Controller (nMPC) based local planner for a Differential Drive Mobile Robot (DDMR) within the ROS Noetic navigation stack.Unlike conventional reactive planners, an nMPC uses a mathematical model (in this case, a kinematic model) to predict future states and optimize them over a defined horizon. This is done by minimizing a cost function while satisfying both soft and hard constraints, such as obstacle distance, velocity bounds, and input limits.The local planner was implemented entirely in Python, utilizing the CasADi framework for formulating the nonlinear optimization problem. The IPOPT solver (Interior Point Optimizer) was used to solve the problem at runtime efficiently.As part of the evaluation, I compared the nMPC planner against established ROS local planners:- Dynamic Window Approach (DWA)- Timed Elastic Band (TEB)The nMPC planner receives a global reference trajectory (e.g., from an RRT-based global planner) and computes optimized control inputs at higher frequency to achieve smooth and safe local obstacle avoidance, even in dynamic and narrow environments.- The system was simulated in Gazebo with a TurtleBot platform and fully integrated with ROS Noetic.- ğŸ³ A GPU-enabled Docker container is provided for fast and reproducible setup.- ğŸ“ The GitHub repository includes the full source code, parameter tuning, scientific paper, and presentation slides.ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/dgpq7y2Yhashtag#Robotics hashtag#MPC hashtag#nMPC hashtag#CasADi hashtag#IPOPT hashtag#PathPlanning hashtag#ROS hashtag#ROSNoetic hashtag#AutonomousSystems hashtag#TurtleBot hashtag#Gazebo hashtag#Python hashtag#MobileRobots hashtag#NonlinearControl hashtag#ControlTheory hashtag#Optimization hashtag#ResearchProject hashtag#OpenSource

ğŸ§µ Multithreading Interview Q&A (Deep & Drive)Q1: What is multithreading in Java?-> Multithreading is a process of executing two or more threads simultaneously for maximum CPU utilization. Each thread runs independently, but they share the same process memory.Q2: How do you create threads in Java?-> Two ways:->Extend the Thread class and override run()->Implement Runnable and pass to the Thread constructorjavaCopyEdit->Runnable task = () -> System.out.println("Thread running"); new Thread(task).start();Q3: Difference between start() and run()?->start() creates a new thread and invokes run() inside it. run() just calls the method in the current thread (no parallelism).Q4: What is the thread lifecycle?->New â†’ Runnable â†’ Running â†’ Blocked/Waiting â†’ Dead. Transitions occur due to start(), I/O, wait/notify, etc.Q5: What are synchronized blocks?->Used to avoid race conditions when multiple threads modify shared   resources. Only one thread can enter a synchronized block for the given lock at a time.javaCopyEditsynchronized(this) { // critical section}Q6: What is the difference between synchronized and Lock?->Lock (like ReentrantLock) offers more control (tryLock, fairness), while synchronized is easier and less error-prone.Q7: What is the use of volatile keyword?->It prevents caching of variables, ensuring visibility of changes across threads.Q8: How do you handle thread communication?->Using wait(), notify(), notifyAll() inside synchronized blocks. Also, CountDownLatch, Semaphore, and  BlockingQueue are in the concurrent API.Q9: Thread-safe collections?->Use ConcurrentHashMap, CopyOnWriteArrayList, or wrap legacy ones via Collections.synchronizedList(...).Q10: How is multithreading used in Spring Boot?->Spring Boot uses multithreading in:Async tasks using @AsyncScheduled jobs (@Scheduled)Web server request handling (Tomcat/Jetty/NIO threads)Parallel data processing with WebClient + Project Reactor (Reactive Programming)hashtag#JavaDeveloper hashtag#TechInterview hashtag#BackendDevelopment hashtag#SpringBoot hashtag#JavaLearning hashtag#ProgrammingTipshashtag#JavaMultithreading hashtag#ConcurrencyInJava hashtag#ThreadSafety hashtag#ParallelProgramming hashtag#JavaThreads hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#JavaTips hashtag#AsynchronousProgramming hashtag#JavaInterview hashtag#JavaConcurrency hashtag#ThreadPool hashtag#CodeWithJava hashtag#MultithreadedApps hashtag#CoreJava hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

ğŸ“Œ Why Our Team is Considering Switching from Redis to Valkey: Real Performance Data and PerspectivesOur backend development team has been looking at Valkey as an alternative to Redis for quite some time, and I recently studied a detailed comparison of these technologies that I'd like to share.â“What is Valkey and why does it matter?Valkey is a fork of Redis that maintained the BSD 3-Clause license after Redis changed its licensing model in spring 2024. The key difference: Valkey remains fully open-source, without an enterprise version or commercial restrictions.â“What did the benchmarks show?Tests based on YCSB demonstrated thatÂ Valkey 8.0 outperforms both Redis 6.2 and Redis 7.2Â in all load scenarios. Particularly interesting is that Redis 7.2 often performs worse than version 6.2, confirming the experience of many teams who encountered regressions when upgrading.âš™ï¸ Technical improvements that impressed us:- Innovative approach to I/O threads: In Redis, I/O threads and the main thread often "wait" for each other. In Valkey, this is fixed â€” threads can work in parallel thanks to the use of atomics and task queues for each I/O thread.- Hash table optimization: Improved processor cache utilization through prefetch, significantly reducing data access latency.- Dual-channel replication: Moving the change buffer to the replica, reducing the risk of Out Of Memory on the primary during intensive workloads.- Key embedding: Storing short keys directly in the structure, saving 10-20% of RAM.- Extended metrics: New monitoring capabilities, including tracking load on individual cluster slots.ğŸ“ What's next?The active developer community around Valkey promises more dynamic project development. We plan to conduct our own testing in our infrastructure before making a final decision, but the initial data looks promising.Has anyone already switched to Valkey in production? I'd love to hear about your experience in the comments!hashtag#backend hashtag#golang hashtag#redis hashtag#ralkey hashtag#HighLoad hashtag#OpenSource

Iâ€™m pleased to share our recent publication in Mechanical Systems and Signal Processing journal, titled:â€œOptimizing bridge modal property estimation via quality-driven crowdsourced smartphone data selectionâ€This study presents a novel approach to improve the accuracy of absolute mode shape identification by evaluating and filtering crowdsourced smartphone-vehicle trip data based on its quality. While mobile sensing using smartphone data offers a scalable and low-cost solution for bridge monitoring, it is often affected by sensor noise, vehicle dynamics, and road surface variability.To address this, we proposed a quality score to quantify each tripâ€™s contribution to the identified mode shape and developed a supervised learning model (using CNNs) to automatically predict the data quality score. Our model was trained and validated using over 900 datasets collected on the Cadore Viaduct in Italy. The results demonstrated that filtering based on data quality can significantly enhance absolute mode shape accuracy.This work underscores the importance of data quality in mobile sensing for structural health monitoring and showcases the integration of data-driven methods into civil infrastructure assessment.I am sincerely grateful to my co-authors â€” Thomas Matarazzo, Soheil Sadeghi Eshkevari, Liam Cronin, and Shamim Pakzad â€” for their valuable contributions and collaboration throughout this work. I would also like to extend my thanks to MIT Senseable City Lab for their support and for providing access to datasets.The full paper is available open access at the following link: https://lnkd.in/dvUPt46thashtag#StructuralHealthMonitoring hashtag#MobileSensing hashtag#CrowdsourcedData hashtag#CivilEngineering hashtag#MachineLearning hashtag#BridgeMonitoring hashtag#MechanicalSystemsAndSignalProcessing hashtag#SHM hashtag#DataQuality hashtag#WaveletTransform

"Sometimes when things fall apart, theyâ€™re actually falling into place."The past few months have brought real challenges and hardshipsâ€”and I donâ€™t want to downplay thatâ€”but they have also uncovered some unexpected gifts and new possibilities. I've been reflecting on how multifaceted change can be:1. Finding community close to home.As a remote worker, Iâ€™ve treasured my colleagues across the country and the world, but Iâ€™ve missed in-person connection. One silver lining of this disruption is discovering a whole network of like-minded professionals right here in Colorado. Dozens of us, doing similar work, were just a few miles apart and never knew it.2. Growing in new directions.Our entire sector is expanding its toolkit. Weâ€™re gaining new skills, discovering new passions, and developing new capabilities. When we come back together, weâ€™ll be bringing more to the table than ever beforeâ€”and channeling that straight into global impact.3. Solidarity over fragmentation.Before all this, our field could feel artificially divided: donors vs. implementers, primes vs. subs, direct hires vs. contractors. But this moment has reminded us that weâ€™re all on one team. When the international development sector returns, weâ€™ll be stronger, more connected, and more united than ever. welcome back Ø¹Ø¯Ù†Ø§ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§Ù„ØºÙŠØ¨Ø© ğŸ˜… ğŸš€ Next Step: SWE.2 â€“ From Requirement to Architecture and Model! ğŸš€Iâ€™m thrilled to share the next phase of my MBD diploma project from OS-Academy â€“ : SWE.2 â€“ Software Architecture Design! ğŸš€In this stage, weâ€™ll take the system requirements defined in SWE.1 and build a modular, maintainable architecture that steers implementation, testing, and future evolution.Hereâ€™s what to expect:1ï¸âƒ£ Architectural Views Break the system into clear functional blocks and define their responsibilities:ğŸ”¹Main State Machine Manages core logic and coordinates inter-module communication.ğŸ”¹Current Limits Calculator Computes safe charge/discharge thresholds based on real-time data.ğŸ”¹SOC & SOH Estimators Tracks battery state-of-charge and state-of-health.ğŸ”¹Balancing Logic Ensures individual cell voltages stay synchronized.2ï¸âƒ£ Interfaces & Data FlowsMap each domain into software modules/packages with precise contracts: ğŸ”¹ Defined fixed-rate tasks(50 ms â” MainSM, 100 ms â” LimitsCalc, 200 ms â” SOC/SOH estimators, 250 ms â” Balancing) ğŸ”¹ Route signals (voltage, temperature, current) via buses and ZOH blocks ğŸ”¹ Store each signal in the Data Dictionary as ğŸ”„ a MTP Signals: (ImportedExtern (inputs) - ExportedToFile (logging) - Localized (module-internal))3ï¸âƒ£ Modeling & PrototypingLeverage MATLAB/Simulink & Stateflow to:ğŸ”¹Prototype each core module and simulate their interactions.ğŸ”¹Auto-generate architecture diagrams directly from models.ğŸ”¹Run Model Advisor checks for MISRA C compliance, execution efficiency, and RAM usage.4ï¸âƒ£ Verification AlignmentEmbed test hooks and traceability throughout:ğŸ”¹MIL/SIL Test Harnesses for unit, integration, and system-level validation.ğŸ”¹Full Requirements â†” Architecture â†” Test Case traceability matrices.ğŸ”¹Automated test-management reports to track coverage and results.ğŸ” Why it matters A well-crafted software architecture is the backbone of a reliable project â€”it makes implementation easier to develop, verify, and evolve. By nailing this SWE.2 step, we set ourselves up for smoother integration (SWE.3) and rigorous validation (SWE.4).ğŸ”— the GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dpww-PjNStay tuned for SWE.3, where we dive into detailed design and implementation, plus start exploring our battery and planetary models! ğŸŒğŸ”‹hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#MBD hashtag#VModel hashtag#SWE2 hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MATLABSimulink hashtag#BMS

GCC15 is out, with prime path coverage! I wrote a paper about the my implementation, the algorithm, and some new developments; notably, that prime path coverage subsumes MC/DC, and that using suffix trees for recording paths can eliminate redundant paths very quickly -- O(nÂ²m) down from O(nÂ²mÂ²), where n is the length of the longest path, and m is the number of paths. This is makes pruning redundant paths very quick as n tends to be small, and m tends to be very large.

Up until recently Amethyst Planner stored everything locally on the user's device. Unfortunately this meant that the user couldn't use the app across multiple devices (or easy switch to a new device).I was surprised to find there wasn't an existing plugin for sync'ing data between Hive and a backend API. We ended up creating TimestampedBox that wraps a Hive Box and provides all the timestamps to support the sync operation. What do you think? How have you approached synchronization and reconciliation across devices and backends?Checkout Amethyst Planner - the task app for hashtag#ADHDers the turns to-dos into dopamine.

Java 24: More than an update â€” a powerful step forward for modern software architecture. hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBRWith the official release of Java 24, Oracle continues to evolve the platform in ways that directly support today's demands for scalability, modularity, and cloud-native design. For professionals like me who architect systems with Hexagonal Architecture (DDD) and deploy on AWS, this release brings substantial benefits.ğŸš€ Key Features in Java 24:âœ… JEP 447 â€“ Statements before super(...) Allows initialization logic before calling the superclass constructor. This enhances flexibility in rich domain models and simplifies base-class inheritance patterns in DDD.âœ… JEP 456 â€“ Unnamed Variables and Patterns (Preview) Reduces boilerplate when using pattern matching, making business logic cleaner and more expressive.âœ… JEP 459 â€“ String Templates (Second Preview) Provides safe and efficient string interpolation â€” ideal for building dynamic responses, configurations, and messages without complex concatenation.âœ… JEP 460 â€“ Vector API (7th Incubator) Enables data-parallel operations for better performance in compute-heavy tasks â€” relevant for analytics or event-driven systems.âœ… JEP 462 â€“ Structured Concurrency (Second Preview) Improves thread lifecycle management and simplifies parallel processing. This is huge for backend services needing concurrency without chaos â€” perfect fit for services deployed via AWS Lambda, ECS, or EKS.ğŸ§± How this strengthens Hexagonal Architecture and DDDJava 24â€™s cleaner syntax and enhanced language constructs allow for: ğŸ”¹ Richer domain modeling without ceremony ğŸ”¹ Easier testing and mocking of application ports ğŸ”¹ Clearer separation of concerns in inbound/outbound adapters ğŸ”¹ Better observability and tracing when paired with AWS services like CloudWatch & X-Rayâ˜ï¸ AWS + Java 24 = Cloud-native powerCombined with AWS, Java 24 enables: âœ… Lighter Lambda functions (faster cold starts with JDK optimizations) âœ… Enhanced developer productivity with CodeWhisperer and Amazon Q Developer âœ… Seamless integration with infrastructure-as-code (CDK, Terraform) and microservices ecosystemsWeâ€™re not just writing code â€” weâ€™re building resilient, scalable ecosystems. Java 24 gives us sharper tools to do that smarter, faster, and cleaner.Are you already experimenting with Java 24? Whatâ€™s your favorite improvement so far?hashtag#Java24 hashtag#HexagonalArchitecture hashtag#DDD hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudNative hashtag#Innovation hashtag#BackendEngineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBR

It's Friday and I'm still working. .One myth about remote work is how people think it's all about working from the "comfort" of your home. .It's not and most of the time, it's not comfortable. Other times, we make plans and forget about them because we get so engrossed in the work we do. Last year, I developed a nonlinear Model Predictive Controller (nMPC) based local planner for a Differential Drive Mobile Robot (DDMR) within the ROS Noetic navigation stack.Unlike conventional reactive planners, an nMPC uses a mathematical model (in this case, a kinematic model) to predict future states and optimize them over a defined horizon. This is done by minimizing a cost function while satisfying both soft and hard constraints, such as obstacle distance, velocity bounds, and input limits.The local planner was implemented entirely in Python, utilizing the CasADi framework for formulating the nonlinear optimization problem. The IPOPT solver (Interior Point Optimizer) was used to solve the problem at runtime efficiently.As part of the evaluation, I compared the nMPC planner against established ROS local planners:- Dynamic Window Approach (DWA)- Timed Elastic Band (TEB)The nMPC planner receives a global reference trajectory (e.g., from an RRT-based global planner) and computes optimized control inputs at higher frequency to achieve smooth and safe local obstacle avoidance, even in dynamic and narrow environments.- The system was simulated in Gazebo with a TurtleBot platform and fully integrated with ROS Noetic.- ğŸ³ A GPU-enabled Docker container is provided for fast and reproducible setup.- ğŸ“ The GitHub repository includes the full source code, parameter tuning, scientific paper, and presentation slides.ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/dgpq7y2Yhashtag#Robotics hashtag#MPC hashtag#nMPC hashtag#CasADi hashtag#IPOPT hashtag#PathPlanning hashtag#ROS hashtag#ROSNoetic hashtag#AutonomousSystems hashtag#TurtleBot hashtag#Gazebo hashtag#Python hashtag#MobileRobots hashtag#NonlinearControl hashtag#ControlTheory hashtag#Optimization hashtag#ResearchProject hashtag#OpenSource

ğŸ§µ Multithreading Interview Q&A (Deep & Drive)Q1: What is multithreading in Java?-> Multithreading is a process of executing two or more threads simultaneously for maximum CPU utilization. Each thread runs independently, but they share the same process memory.Q2: How do you create threads in Java?-> Two ways:->Extend the Thread class and override run()->Implement Runnable and pass to the Thread constructorjavaCopyEdit->Runnable task = () -> System.out.println("Thread running"); new Thread(task).start();Q3: Difference between start() and run()?->start() creates a new thread and invokes run() inside it. run() just calls the method in the current thread (no parallelism).Q4: What is the thread lifecycle?->New â†’ Runnable â†’ Running â†’ Blocked/Waiting â†’ Dead. Transitions occur due to start(), I/O, wait/notify, etc.Q5: What are synchronized blocks?->Used to avoid race conditions when multiple threads modify shared   resources. Only one thread can enter a synchronized block for the given lock at a time.javaCopyEditsynchronized(this) { // critical section}Q6: What is the difference between synchronized and Lock?->Lock (like ReentrantLock) offers more control (tryLock, fairness), while synchronized is easier and less error-prone.Q7: What is the use of volatile keyword?->It prevents caching of variables, ensuring visibility of changes across threads.Q8: How do you handle thread communication?->Using wait(), notify(), notifyAll() inside synchronized blocks. Also, CountDownLatch, Semaphore, and  BlockingQueue are in the concurrent API.Q9: Thread-safe collections?->Use ConcurrentHashMap, CopyOnWriteArrayList, or wrap legacy ones via Collections.synchronizedList(...).Q10: How is multithreading used in Spring Boot?->Spring Boot uses multithreading in:Async tasks using @AsyncScheduled jobs (@Scheduled)Web server request handling (Tomcat/Jetty/NIO threads)Parallel data processing with WebClient + Project Reactor (Reactive Programming)hashtag#JavaDeveloper hashtag#TechInterview hashtag#BackendDevelopment hashtag#SpringBoot hashtag#JavaLearning hashtag#ProgrammingTipshashtag#JavaMultithreading hashtag#ConcurrencyInJava hashtag#ThreadSafety hashtag#ParallelProgramming hashtag#JavaThreads hashtag#JavaPerformance hashtag#JavaTips hashtag#AsynchronousProgramming hashtag#JavaInterview hashtag#JavaConcurrency hashtag#ThreadPool hashtag#CodeWithJava hashtag#MultithreadedApps hashtag#CoreJava hashtag#SoftwareEngineering
